{{short description|American actor}} {{Infobox person | name = John Cho | image = John Cho in 2018.jpg | caption = Cho in June 2018 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1972|6|16}} | birth_place = [[Seoul]], South Korea | birth_name = Cho Yo-Han | nationality = American | occupation = Actor | years_active = 1997–present | spouse = {{marriage|Kerri Higuchi|2006}} | children = 2 | alma_mater = [[University of California, Berkeley]] | module = {{Infobox Korean name|child=yes|color=transparent | hangul = 조요한 | rr = Jo Yo(-)han | mr = Cho Yohan }} }}
'''John Cho''' (born '''Cho Yo-Han'''; June 16, 1972)<ref name="tvg">{{cite web |url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/john-cho/bio/157818/ |title=John Cho Biography |publisher=[[TV Guide|TVGuide.com]] |access-date=July 7, 2016 |archive-date=September 20, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150920130151/http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/john-cho/bio/157818/}}</ref><!--Cited source TV Guide gives birth name Cho Yo Han--><!--TV Guide link is live but birth date is only in archived version--> is an American actor known for his roles as Harold Lee in the ''[[Harold & Kumar]]'' films, and [[Hikaru Sulu]] in the ''[[Star Trek]]'' reboot film series.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2018/07/john-cho-starring-searching|title=Two Years After #StarringJohnCho, John Cho Is Finally a Leading Man|last=Chi|first=Paul|date=July 26, 2018|website=Vanity Fair|language=en|access-date=2020-03-17}}</ref>
Early in his career, Cho also starred in the Asian American–centered films ''[[Better Luck Tomorrow]]'' (2002), ''[[Shopping for Fangs]]'' (1997), and ''[[Yellow (1998 film)|Yellow]]'' (1998). In 2017, he received critical acclaim for his performance in the hit indie film ''[[Columbus (2017 film)|Columbus]]''. In 2018, he starred in the thriller film ''[[Searching (film)|Searching]]'', making him the first Asian American actor in history to headline a mainstream thriller film in Hollywood. He was nominated for the [[Independent Spirit Award for Best Male Lead]] for his performance in ''Searching''.
He also made history in American television as the first Asian-American actor cast as a romantic lead when he starred as Henry Higgs in the 2014 sitcom ''[[Selfie (TV series)|Selfie]].'' In addition to his role in ''Selfie'', Cho has had lead roles in series such as ''[[FlashForward]]'' and ''[[Off Centre]]'', and recurring roles in ''[[Sleepy Hollow (TV series)|Sleepy Hollow]]'' and ''[[Difficult People]]''.
== Early life == Born in [[Seoul]], South Korea, Cho moved to the United States in 1978.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://time.com/collection-post/5042063/american-voices-john-cho/|title=John Cho Thinks His Immigration Story Makes Him a True Citizen|last=Falcone|first=Dana Rose|date=December 20, 2017|website=TIME.com|access-date=2020-03-17}}</ref> He was raised in [[Los Angeles]], where his family settled after living in [[Houston]], [[Seattle]], [[Daly City, California]] and [[Monterey Park, California]].<ref name="Kevin" /><ref name="UCLA">{{cite web|url=https://international.ucla.edu/institute/article/110087|title=The Game-Changer: An Interview with John Cho|last=Wang|first=Oliver|date=July 3, 2009|publisher=Asia Pacific Arts ([[UCLA Asia Institute]])|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140121080301/http://www.asiaarts.ucla.edu/090703/article.asp?parentID=110087|archive-date=January 21, 2014}}</ref> His father was a minister in the [[Churches of Christ|Church of Christ]] and was originally from North Korea.<ref name="Kevin">''Kevin Pollak's Chat Show,'' Hulu.com and Ustream, episode 96</ref><ref name="UCLA" /><ref>{{cite web |title=What to watch |url=http://www.aoltv.com/2011/10/27/john-cho-kal-penn-different-white-house-experiences-video/ |website=AOL.com |access-date=2015-12-02}}</ref> Cho graduated from [[Herbert Hoover High School (Glendale)|Herbert Hoover High School]], in [[Glendale, California]], in 1990.<ref name="UCLA" /><ref>{{cite news|last=Buchanan|first=Jason|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/person/224268/John-Cho/biography|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080511153921/http://movies.nytimes.com/person/224268/John-Cho/biography|url-status=dead|archive-date=2008-05-11|department=Movies & TV Dept.|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=2008|title=John Cho}}</ref>
Cho attended the [[University of California, Berkeley]]. In 1994, he toured nationally for a stage production of [[Maxine Hong Kingston]]'s ''[[The Woman Warrior]]'' by the [[Berkeley Repertory Theatre]]. He graduated in 1996 with a [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] degree in English.<ref name="UCLA" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/article/John-Cho-rises-to-the-top-with-Harold-s-help-3217677.php|title=John Cho rises to the top, with Harold's help|last=Hartlaub|first=Peter|date=2008-04-23|website=SFGate|access-date=2020-03-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://reunions.berkeley.edu/spotlight/john-cho|title=John Cho|last=Varian|first=Maya Felipa|date=2016-10-11|website=Cal Reunions|language=en|access-date=2020-03-17}}</ref>
== Career == After graduation, Cho taught English at [[Pacific Hills School]] in [[West Hollywood, California]], while acting at [[East West Players]] in downtown [[Los Angeles]].<ref name="Kevin" /><ref name="UCLA" /> There, he appeared in Edward Sakamoto's ''The Taste of Kona Coffee'' in 1996 and in Euijoon Kim's movie ''My Tired Broke Ass Pontificating Slapstick Funk'' in 2000.<ref>[http://eastwestplayers.org/about_us/production_history/mybrokeass.htm EWP 34th Season] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110406114333/http://www.eastwestplayers.org/about_us/production_history/mybrokeass.htm |date=2011-04-06 }} on [[East West Players]] site</ref>
Cho gained attention with a small role as "MILF Guy #2" in the 1999 comedy ''[[American Pie (film)|American Pie]]'', in which he popularized the slang term [[MILF (slang)|MILF]].<ref name="UCLA" /> Cho reprised the role in three sequels: ''[[American Pie 2]]'', ''[[American Wedding]]'', and the latest installment ''[[American Reunion]]'' in which he has a much larger role. His character initially had no name but he was given the name "John" in the third film, named after Cho himself.
Cho guest-starred on ''[[Charmed]]'' as a [[Dead Man Dating|ghost]] in 1998 and was one of the stars of the short-lived situation comedy ''[[Off Centre]]'' from 2001 to 2002. He was a costar on the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] sitcom ''[[Kitchen Confidential (TV series)|Kitchen Confidential]]'' based on [[Anthony Bourdain]]'s [[Kitchen Confidential: Adventures in the Culinary Underbelly|best-selling book]]. He had supporting roles in the [[science fiction|sci-fi]] comedy ''[[Evolution (2001 film)|Evolution]]'' directed by [[Ivan Reitman]], ''[[Down to Earth (2001 film)|Down to Earth]]'' starring [[Chris Rock]], and ''[[Bowfinger]]'' with [[Steve Martin]].
In 2002, Cho had a starring role in the ensemble cast of [[Justin Lin]]'s ''[[Better Luck Tomorrow]]'', a drama focusing on the travails of a group of [[Asian American]]s living in Southern California who are academically successful but socially discontented, and as a result engage in wantonly violent, criminal behavior. It was well received by critics, with Elvis Mitchell of the ''New York Times'' describing Cho's character's "lazy magnetism of which he is charmingly aware".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/11/movies/film-review-teenagers-determined-to-damage-their-resumes.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm |title=Film Review; Teenages Determined to Damage Their Resumes |first=Elvis |last=Mitchell |access-date=26 August 2012 |work=The New York Times |date=2003-04-11}}</ref> Later that year, the movie ''[[Big Fat Liar]]'' was released, in which Cho played a Hong Kong-based movie director. He refused to do the accent scripted for his character. The director worked with him to re-develop the role.<ref>Sullivan, Gail (October 9, 2014), [https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2014/10/09/john-cho-of-selfie-wants-roles-outside-any-asian-stereotype-2/ "John Cho of 'Selfie': 'I experienced racism'"]. The Washington Post. Retrieved June 16, 2015.</ref>
Cho had a successful starring role as Harold Lee in 2004's ''[[Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle]]'' and reprised the role in 2008's ''[[Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay]]'' which raked in $38{{nbsp}}million at the theaters,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=haroldandkumar2.htm |title=Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay |website=boxofficemojo.com}}</ref> and again in 2011's ''[[A Very Harold & Kumar 3D Christmas]]'' which made $35{{nbsp}}million.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=haroldandkumar3.htm |title=A Very Harold & Kumar 3D Christmas |publisher=boxofficemojo.com}}</ref> Cho's role in the popular franchise was written specifically for him by [[Hayden Schlossberg]], and Cho has recounted that when Schlossberg first approached him with the role, he was initially suspicious.<ref name="Kevin" />
Cho appeared on July 2004 issue of ''[[KoreAm Journal]]'' and in September 2006 was cast in NBC's new comedy ''[[The Singles Table]]'', but the series never aired due to changes in scheduling and production. In 2006 and again in 2009,<ref>[https://people.com/celebrity/the-sexiest-men-alive-2009/ People Magazine Sexiest Men Alive 2009]</ref> Cho was selected as one of the sexiest men alive in ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' magazine.
[[File:10.8.17TheExorcistByLuigiNovi043.jpg|thumb|Cho, right, promoting ''[[The Exorcist (TV series)|The Exorcist]]'' at the 2017 [[New York Comic Con]]. Beside him are his co-stars (left to right) [[Ben Daniels]], [[Zuleikha Robinson]], and [[Kurt Egyiawan]].]] In 2007, Cho was added to the cast of ''[[Ugly Betty]]'' as a recurring character. Cho plays Kenny, a best friend of accountant [[Henry Grubstick]] (played by [[Christopher Gorham]]). Cho played helmsman [[Hikaru Sulu]] in [[J. J. Abrams]]'s feature film ''[[Star Trek (film)|Star Trek]]''.<ref>{{cite news |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/content_display/news/e3if4ef26bbb490c2c53a944c8e92a50006 |date=2007-10-12 |title=Final frontier for Cho, Pegg |first=Borys |last=Kit}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/SHOWBIZ/Movies/03/12/john.cho.ap/index.html |title=John Cho: 'Trek' role is 'daunting' |agency=Associated Press |publisher=CNN |date=2008-03-12}}</ref> Manohla Dargis of ''The New York Times'' praised him, along with [[Anton Yelchin]], [[Chris Pine]], and [[Zachary Quinto]], for making their roles "ultimately and rather wonderfully their own".<ref>{{cite news |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://movies.nytimes.com/2009/05/08/movies/08trek.html |title=Movie Review: 'Star Trek' |first=Manohla |last=Dargis |author-link=Manohla Dargis |date=7 May 2009 |access-date=27 Aug 2012}}</ref>
Cho appeared in [[Nas]]'s "[[Be a Nigger Too]]" music video along with various celebrities, and had a guest appearance on the sitcom ''[[How I Met Your Mother]]'', in the episode "[[I'm Not That Guy]]" where he played a partner in an evil law firm. Of the latter, Staci Krause of [[IGN]], wrote that Cho was "the scene stealer in this episode" and that she would "definitely like to see more of him" in the series.<ref name="IGN">{{cite web |publisher=IGN |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2007/10/30/how-i-met-your-mother-im-not-that-guy-review |title=How I Met Your Mother: 'I'm Not That Guy' Review |date=2007-10-30}}</ref>
From 2009 to 2010, Cho starred in the television series ''[[FlashForward]]'' as FBI Special Agent [[Demetri Noh]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/Fall-TV-ABC-1006175.aspx |title=Fall TV: ABC's Official Schedule Revisits V, Moves Betty and Says Adieu to Who? |first=Joyce |last=Eng |work=[[TV Guide]] |date=2009-05-19}}</ref> His character was originally slated to be killed off during what turned out to be the show's only season, but after his turn as Sulu in ''Star Trek'' boosted his popularity, the producers revised the show's storyline so that he survived, in an attempt to boost declining ratings.<ref name="FlashForward Keck">{{cite web |last=Keck |first=William |author-link=William Keck |title=Keck's Exclusives: Gabrielle Union FlashForwards to New Series |url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/Kecks-Exclusives-Gabrielle-1019728.aspx |work=TV Guide |date=June 18, 2010 |access-date=July 9, 2010}}</ref>
Cho starred as Henry Higgs in the short-lived sitcom ''[[Selfie (TV series)|Selfie]]'', a retooling of the play ''[[Pygmalion (play)|Pygmalion]]'' by [[George Bernard Shaw]],<ref>Doll, Jen (October 20, 2014), [https://www.bloomberg.com/bw/articles/2014-10-16/review-abcs-selfie-fails-to-get-the-internet-right "YOU CAN'T DO THAT ON TELEVISION]." ''Business Week''. (4399):70</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/2014-year-in-review/was-2014-banner-year-asian-americans-television-n271176 |title=Was 2014 A Banner Year for Asian Americans on Television? |publisher=[[NBC News]] |date=December 27, 2014 |access-date=August 20, 2017 |archive-date=August 20, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170820131023/http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/2014-year-in-review/was-2014-banner-year-asian-americans-television-n271176 |url-status=live}}</ref> becoming the first Asian American to play a romantic lead on a U.S. television series.
In 2018, Cho starred in the film ''[[Searching (film)|Searching]]'', playing a man combing social media for clues to his daughter's disappearance. He was the first Asian-American actor to headline a mainstream thriller in Hollywood.<ref>{{cite web |last=General |first=Ryan |url=https://nextshark.com/john-cho-searching-thriller-asian-actor/ |title=John Cho Makes History as the First Asian Actor Leading a Hollywood Thriller in 'Searching' |publisher=Nextshark.com |date=2018-07-25 |access-date=2018-07-29}}</ref> Also in 2018, he was presented with the [[List of San Diego International Film Festival award winners|Spotlight Award]] at the [[San Diego International Film Festival]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://sdfilmfest.com/night-of-the-stars-tribute/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190403112641/https://sdfilmfest.com/night-of-the-stars-tribute/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=2019-04-03 |title=Night Of The Stars Tribute {{!}} San Diego International Film Festival|date=2019-04-03|access-date=2019-10-11}}</ref>
In April 2019, [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] reported that Cho had been cast as [[Spike Spiegel]] in a live-action version of the ''[[Cowboy Bebop]]'' series.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2019/tv/news/cowboy-bebop-netflix-live-action-series-cast-1203180399/ |title=''Cowboy Bebop'': John Cho, Mustafa Shakir Among Four Cast in Netflix Live-Action Series |last=Otterson |first=Joe |work=Variety |date=April 4, 2019 |access-date=April 6, 2019}}</ref> However, production shut down when Cho suffered a knee injury in October and remained shut down until late September 2020 due to the [[COVID-19 pandemic]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Andreeva |first=Nellie |title=''Cowboy Bebop'': Netflix Series Shuts Down Production For 7-9 Months Following Star John Cho On-Set Injury |url=https://deadline.com/2019/10/cowboy-bebop-netflix-series-shuts-down-production-7-9-months-hiatus-star-john-cho-on-set-injury-1202764024/ |website=Deadline |date=October 18, 2019 |access-date=October 25, 2019}}</ref>
==Musical career== Cho is the lead singer for Viva La Union (formerly known as Left of Zed),<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.asiaarts.ucla.edu/090703/article.asp?parentID=110145|title=Asia Pacific Arts: The Game-Changer: An Interview with John Cho (part 2)|last=Wang|first=Oliver|date=2009-07-03|website=Asia Pacific Arts|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090709165706/http://www.asiaarts.ucla.edu/090703/article.asp?parentID=110145|archive-date=2009-07-09|access-date=2020-03-17}}</ref> a Los Angeles [[garage rock]] band composed of former [[University of California at Berkeley|Berkeley]] and [[University of Southern California|USC]] students. They have one album, self-titled, while their song "Chinese Baby" is featured on the [[Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay#Soundtrack|''Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay'' soundtrack]].
==Personal life== Cho married actress Kerri Higuchi in 2006. They have a son, born in 2008,<ref name="People Baby">{{cite web |title=John Cho and wife Kerri expecting first child |url=https://people.com/parents/john-cho-and-wi/ |work=[[People (magazine)|People]] |date=April 13, 2008 |access-date=February 13, 2019 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111209125155/http://celebritybabies.people.com/2008/04/13/john-cho-and-wi/ |archive-date=December 9, 2011}}</ref> and a daughter, born in 2013.<ref name="People second baby">{{cite web |title=John Cho and wife Kerri have second child |url=https://people.com/parents/go-on-identity-thief-john-cho-welcomes-a-daughter/ |work=[[People (magazine)|People]] |date=February 11, 2013 |access-date=February 13, 2019}}</ref> As of 2015, he and his family reside in Los Angeles, California.<ref>{{cite web |title=John Cho |url=http://www.tv.com/people/john-cho/biography/ |website=TV.com |access-date=2015-12-01}}</ref> He is close to his father, a former preacher, and would like to play a role in the story of his father's generation, growing up in North Korea through the [[Korean War]].<ref name=":3">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=94HUM3S_Gzg|title=John Cho On Playing The Asian-American Stoner Stereotype|work=Larry King Now}}</ref>
Cho has indicated he has found freedom in being Harold in the ''Harold and Kumar'' films because the stoner character goes against the grain of Asian Americans onscreen.<ref name=":3" /> He has said he has experienced racism throughout his career in Hollywood and that he tries to take roles that do not perpetuate Asian stereotypes.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/codeswitch/2014/09/28/352046466/selfie-s-choice-john-cho-gets-an-unlikely-shot-as-a-romantic-lead|title=In 'Selfie', John Cho Gets An Unlikely Shot As A Romantic Lead|publisher=[[National Public Radio]]|access-date=2015-12-02}}</ref> When asked to do an Asian accent for ''Big Fat Liar'', Cho refused. "I don't want to do this role in a kid's comedy, with an accent, because I don't want young people laughing at an accent inadvertently", he wrote.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Sullivan|first=Gail|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2014/10/09/john-cho-of-selfie-wants-roles-outside-any-asian-stereotype-2/|title=John Cho of 'Selfie': 'I experienced racism'|date=2014-10-09|newspaper=The Washington Post|access-date=2015-11-30|issn=0190-8286}}</ref> In a 2015 tweet he said, "[[Whitewashing in film|Stop turning Asian roles white]]. It's bullshit and we all know it."<ref>{{Cite tweet|first=John (verified account)|last=Cho|title=Stop turning Asian roles white.|date=March 24, 2015|user=JohnTheCho|number=580552681711923200|access-date=November 30, 2015|archive-date=May 11, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160511023752/https://twitter.com/johnthecho/status/580552681711923200|url-status=live}}</ref> On being the first Asian to play a romantic lead on a U.S. television series, he described it as being "revolutionary" and a "personal revolution" for him because of its uniqueness in Hollywood. "Asians narratively in shows are insignificant. They're the cop, or waitress, or whatever it is. You see them in the background. So to be in this position ... is bit of a landmark," he has said on the inability of Asians getting offered such roles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/victoria-namkung/tvs-first-asian-romantic-lead_b_5878380.html|title=Will John Cho Be Television's First Asian Romantic Lead?|website=The Huffington Post|date=25 September 2014|access-date=2015-12-02}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|last=Wong|first=Tony|url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/television/2014/07/16/star_treks_john_cho_breaks_barriers_as_romantic_lead_i_would_call_this_revolutionary.html|title="Asians narratively in shows are insignificant," says John Cho, the romantic lead in the fall series Selfie. "So to be in this position ... is a bit of a landmark."|date=2014-07-16|newspaper=The Toronto Star|access-date=2015-11-30|issn=0319-0781}}</ref>
In 2016, Cho was the face of the "#StarringJohnCho" social movement and hashtag campaign, created by William Yu, wherein Cho is Photoshopped onto existing movie posters as the male lead. The purpose of the project was to call attention to the lack of opportunities for Asian American actors in Hollywood.<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite web|title=#STARRINGJOHNCHO|url=http://starringjohncho.com/|access-date=2020-08-27|website=#STARRINGJOHNCHO|language=en-US}}</ref>
Cho supported the 2012 re-election campaign of Democratic U.S. President [[Barack Obama]].<ref name="hollywooddonors">(2011-07-16) {{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0711/59184.html|title=Hollywood stars open wallets for Obama|access-date=2011-07-16}}</ref>
